226 /*

228 Used to check that no spatial attributes are declared unless

230 */
231 #define HA_CAN_GEOMETRY (1 << 4)
232 /*
233 Reading keys in random order is as fast as reading keys in sort order
234 (Used by filesort to decide if we should sort key + data or key +
235 pointer-to-row.)
236 */
237 #define HA_FAST_KEY_READ (1 << 5)
238 /*
239 Set the following flag if we on delete should force all key to be read

255 #define HA_NO_BLOBS (1 << 9) /* Doesn't support blobs */

257 Is the storage engine capable of defining an index of a prefix on

261 /*
262 Auto increment fields can be part of a multi-part key. For second part
263 auto-increment keys, the auto_incrementing is done in handler.cc
264 */
265 #define HA_AUTO_PART_KEY (1 << 11)
266 /*
267 Can't define a table without primary key (and cannot handle a table
268 with hidden primary key)

270 #define HA_REQUIRE_PRIMARY_KEY (1 << 12)
271 /*
272 Does the counter of records after the info call specify an exact
273 value or not. If it does this flag is set.
274 */
275 #define HA_STATS_RECORDS_IS_EXACT (1 << 13)
276 /// Not in use.
277 #define HA_UNUSED14 (1 << 14)
278 /*
279 This parameter is set when the handler will also return the primary key
280 when doing read-only-key on another index, i.e., if we get the primary
281 key columns for free when we do an index read (usually, it also implies
282 that HA_PRIMARY_KEY_REQUIRED_FOR_POSITION flag is set).
283 */
284 #define HA_PRIMARY_KEY_IN_READ_INDEX (1 << 15)
285 /*
286 If HA_PRIMARY_KEY_REQUIRED_FOR_POSITION is set, it means that to position()
287 uses a primary key given by the record argument.
288 Without primary key, we can't call position().
289 If not set, the position is returned as the current rows position

292 #define HA_PRIMARY_KEY_REQUIRED_FOR_POSITION (1 << 16)
293 #define HA_CAN_RTREEKEYS (1 << 17)
294 /// Not in use.
295 #define HA_UNUSED18
296 /*

298 If there is no primary key, all columns needs to be read on update and delete
299 */
300 #define HA_PRIMARY_KEY_REQUIRED_FOR_DELETE (1 << 19)
301 /*
302 Indexes on prefixes of character fields are not allowed.

304 #define HA_NO_PREFIX_CHAR_KEYS (1 << 20)

306 Does the storage engine support fulltext indexes.

313 #define HA_CAN_SQL_HANDLER (1 << 22)
314 /*

317 #define HA_NO_AUTO_INCREMENT (1 << 23)

319 Supports CHECKSUM option in CREATE TABLE (MyISAM feature).

322 /*
323 Table data are stored in separate files (for lower_case_table_names).
324 Should file names always be in lower case (used by engines that map
325 table names to file names.

327 #define HA_FILE_BASED (1 << 26)
328 #define HA_NO_VARCHAR (1 << 27)

330 Is the storage engine capable of handling bit fields.

332 #define HA_CAN_BIT_FIELD (1 << 28)
333 #define HA_ANY_INDEX_MAY_BE_UNIQUE (1 << 30)

335 #define HA_COUNT_ROWS_INSTANT (1LL << 32) /* records() gives exact count*/
336 /* Has it's own method of binlog logging */
337 #define HA_HAS_OWN_BINLOGGING (1LL << 33)
338 /*
339 Engine is capable of row-format and statement-format logging,

341 */
342 #define HA_BINLOG_ROW_CAPABLE (1LL << 34)
343 #define HA_BINLOG_STMT_CAPABLE (1LL << 35)
344 /*
345 When a multiple key conflict happens in a REPLACE command mysql
346 expects the conflicts to be reported in the ascending order of
347 key names.
348
349 For e.g.
350
351 CREATE TABLE t1 (a INT, UNIQUE (a), b INT NOT NULL, UNIQUE (b), c INT NOT
352 NULL, INDEX(c));
353
354 REPLACE INTO t1 VALUES (1,1,1),(2,2,2),(2,1,3);
355
356 MySQL expects the conflict with 'a' to be reported before the conflict with
357 'b'.
358
359 If the underlying storage engine does not report the conflicting keys in
360 ascending order, it causes unexpected errors when the REPLACE command is
361 executed.
362
363 This flag helps the underlying SE to inform the server that the keys are not
364 ordered.
365 */
366 #define HA_DUPLICATE_KEY_NOT_IN_ORDER (1LL << 36)
367 /*
368 Engine supports REPAIR TABLE. Used by CHECK TABLE FOR UPGRADE if an
369 incompatible table is detected. If this flag is set, CHECK TABLE FOR UPGRADE
370 will report ER_TABLE_NEEDS_UPGRADE, otherwise ER_TABLE_NEED_REBUILD.
371 */
372 #define HA_CAN_REPAIR (1LL << 37)
373
374 /*
375 Set of all binlog flags. Currently only contain the capabilities
376 flags.
377 */
378 #define HA_BINLOG_FLAGS (HA_BINLOG_ROW_CAPABLE | HA_BINLOG_STMT_CAPABLE)

380 /**
381 The handler supports read before write removal optimization
382
383 Read before write removal may be used for storage engines which support
384 write without previous read of the row to be updated. Handler returning
385 this flag must implement start_read_removal() and end_read_removal().
386 The handler may return "fake" rows constructed from the key of the row
387 asked for. This is used to optimize UPDATE and DELETE by reducing the
388 number of round-trips between handler and storage engine.
389
390 Example:
391 UPDATE a=1 WHERE pk IN (@<keys@>)
392
393 @verbatim
394 mysql_update()
395 {
396 if (<conditions for starting read removal>)
397 start_read_removal()
398 -> handler returns true if read removal supported for this table/query
399
400 while(read_record("pk=<key>"))
401 -> handler returns fake row with column "pk" set to <key>
402
403 ha_update_row()
404 -> handler sends write "a=1" for row with "pk=<key>"
405
406 end_read_removal()
407 -> handler returns the number of rows actually written
408 }
409 @endverbatim
410
411 @note This optimization in combination with batching may be used to
412 remove even more round-trips.
413 */
414 #define HA_READ_BEFORE_WRITE_REMOVAL (1LL << 38)
415
416 /*
417 Engine supports extended fulltext API
418 */
419 #define HA_CAN_FULLTEXT_EXT (1LL << 39)
420
421 /*
422 Storage engine doesn't synchronize result set with expected table contents.
423 Used by replication slave to check if it is possible to retrieve rows from
424 the table when deciding whether to do a full table scan, index scan or hash
425 scan while applying a row event.
426 */
427 #define HA_READ_OUT_OF_SYNC (1LL << 40)
428
429 /*
430 Storage engine supports table export using the
431 FLUSH TABLE <table_list> FOR EXPORT statement.
432 */
433 #define HA_CAN_EXPORT (1LL << 41)
434
435 /*
436 The handler don't want accesses to this table to

439 #define HA_BLOCK_CONST_TABLE (1LL << 42)

446 /**
447 Storage engine doesn't support LOCK TABLE ... READ LOCAL locks
448 but doesn't want to use handler::store_lock() API for upgrading
449 them to LOCK TABLE ... READ locks, for example, because it doesn't
450 use THR_LOCK locks at all.
451 */
452 #define HA_NO_READ_LOCAL_LOCK (1LL << 44)
453
454 /**
455 A storage engine is compatible with the attachable transaction requirements
456 means that
457
458 - either SE detects the fact that THD::ha_data was reset and starts a new
459 attachable transaction, closes attachable transaction on close_connection
460 and resumes regular (outer) transaction when THD::ha_data is restored;
461
462 - or SE completely ignores THD::ha_data and close_connection like MyISAM
463 does.
464 */
465 #define HA_ATTACHABLE_TRX_COMPATIBLE (1LL << 45)

525 /*
526 Bits in index_flags(index_number) for what you can do with index.
527 If you do not implement indexes, just return zero here.
528 */
529 /*
530 Does the index support read next, this is assumed in the server
531 code and never checked so all indexes must support this.
532 Note that the handler can be used even if it doesn't have any index.
533 */
534 #define HA_READ_NEXT 1 /* TODO really use this flag */
535 /*
536 Can the index be used to scan backwards (supports ::index_prev).
537 */
538 #define HA_READ_PREV 2
539 /*
540 Can the index deliver its record in index order. Typically true for
541 all ordered indexes and not true for hash indexes. Used to set keymap
542 part_of_sortkey.
543 This keymap is only used to find indexes usable for resolving an ORDER BY
544 in the query. Thus in most cases index_read will work just fine without
545 order in result production. When this flag is set it is however safe to
546 order all output started by index_read since most engines do this. With
547 read_multi_range calls there is a specific flag setting order or not
548 order so in those cases ordering of index output can be avoided.
549 */
550 #define HA_READ_ORDER 4
551 /*
552 Specify whether index can handle ranges, typically true for all
553 ordered indexes and not true for hash indexes.
554 Used by optimiser to check if ranges (as key >= 5) can be optimised
555 by index.
556 */
557 #define HA_READ_RANGE 8
558 /*
559 Can't use part key searches. This is typically true for hash indexes
560 and typically not true for ordered indexes.
561 */
562 #define HA_ONLY_WHOLE_INDEX 16
563 /*
564 Index does not store NULL values, even if the column is nullable.
565 (KEY::flags may still contain HA_NULL_PART_KEY)
566 If the key has a NULL-value, the handler need to do a full table scan
567 instead of using this key. This is typically true for NDB hash indexes.
568 */
569 #define HA_TABLE_SCAN_ON_NULL 32
570 /*
571 Does the storage engine support index-only scans on this index.
572 Enables use of HA_EXTRA_KEYREAD and HA_EXTRA_NO_KEYREAD
573 Used to set Key_map keys_for_keyread and to check in optimiser for
574 index-only scans. When doing a read under HA_EXTRA_KEYREAD the handler
575 only have to fill in the columns the key covers. If
576 HA_PRIMARY_KEY_IN_READ_INDEX is set then also the PRIMARY KEY columns
577 must be updated in the row.
578 */
579 #define HA_KEYREAD_ONLY 64
580 /*
581 Index scan will not return records in rowid order. Not guaranteed to be
582 set for unordered (e.g. HASH) indexes.
583 */
584 #define HA_KEY_SCAN_NOT_ROR 128

628 /**
629 Options for the START TRANSACTION statement.
630
631 Note that READ ONLY and READ WRITE are logically mutually exclusive.
632 This is enforced by the parser and depended upon by trans_begin().
633
634 We need two flags instead of one in order to differentiate between
635 situation when no READ WRITE/ONLY clause were given and thus transaction
636 is implicitly READ WRITE and the case when READ WRITE clause was used
637 explicitly.
638 */
639
640 // WITH CONSISTENT SNAPSHOT option
641 static const uint MYSQL_START_TRANS_OPT_WITH_CONS_SNAPSHOT = 1;
642 // READ ONLY option
643 static const uint MYSQL_START_TRANS_OPT_READ_ONLY = 2;
644 // READ WRITE option
645 static const uint MYSQL_START_TRANS_OPT_READ_WRITE = 4;
646 // HIGH PRIORITY option
647 static const uint MYSQL_START_TRANS_OPT_HIGH_PRIORITY = 8;

974 /** Clone operation types. */

976 /** Caller must block all write operation to the SE. */

981
982 /** For transactional SE, track page changes to support concurrent dml */

988

1243 typedef ulonglong my_xid; // this line is the same as in log_event.h
1244 /**
1245 Enumeration of possible states for externally coordinated transactions (XA).
1246 */
1247 enum class enum_ha_recover_xa_state : int {
1248 NOT_FOUND = -1, // Trnasaction not found
1249 PREPARED_IN_SE = 0, // Transaction is prepared in SEs
1250 PREPARED_IN_TC = 1, // Transaction is prepared in SEs and TC
1251 COMMITTED_WITH_ONEPHASE = 2, // Transaction was one-phase committed
1252 COMMITTED = 3, // Transaction was committed
1253 ROLLEDBACK = 4 // Transaction was rolled back
1254 };
1255 /**
1256 Single occurrence set of XIDs of internally coordinated transactions
1257 found as been committed in the transaction coordinator state.
1258 */
1259 using Xid_commit_list =
1260 std::unordered_set<my_xid, std::hash<my_xid>, std::equal_to<my_xid>,
1261 Mem_root_allocator<my_xid>>;
1262
1263 /**
1264 Class to maintain list of externally coordinated transactions and their
1265 current state at recovery.
1266 */
1267 class Xa_state_list {
1268 public:
1269 using pair = std::pair<const XID, enum_ha_recover_xa_state>;
1270 using allocator = Mem_root_allocator<Xa_state_list::pair>;
1271 using list = std::map<XID, enum_ha_recover_xa_state, std::less<XID>,
1272 Xa_state_list::allocator>;
1273 using iterator = std::map<XID, enum_ha_recover_xa_state, std::less<XID>,
1274 Xa_state_list::allocator>::iterator;
1275 using instantiation_tuple = std::tuple<
1276 std::unique_ptr<MEM_ROOT>, std::unique_ptr<Xa_state_list::allocator>,
1277 std::unique_ptr<Xa_state_list::list>, std::unique_ptr<Xa_state_list>>;
1278
1279 /**
1280 Class constructor.
1281
1282 @param populated_by_tc The underlying list of XIDs and transaction
1283 states, after being populated by the transaction
1284 coodinator.
1285 */
1286 Xa_state_list(Xa_state_list::list &populated_by_tc);
1287 43878 virtual ~Xa_state_list() = default;
1288
1289 /**
1290 Searches the underlying map to find an key that corresponds to the
1291 parameter.
1292
1293 @param to_find The XID to find within the underlying map.
1294
1295 @return Ha_recover_states::NOT_FOUND if the transaction wasn't found,
1296 the state of the transaction, otherwise.
1297 */
1298 enum_ha_recover_xa_state find(XID const &to_find);
1299 /**
1300 Adds a transaction and state to the underlying map. If the given XID
1301 already exists in the underlying map, the associated state changes according
1302 to the following rules:
1303
1304 - If the parameter state is `PREPARED_IN_SE` it means that the
1305 transaction didn't reach PREPARED_IN_TC, COMMIT or ROLLBACK for
1306 sure. In that case:
1307 . If other participants state is `COMMITTED`/`ROLLEDBACK`, it would
1308 mean that it's a state inherited from a previous execution with the
1309 same XID and we should set the state to `PREPARED_IN_SE`.
1310 . If other participants state is `PREPARED_IN_TC`/
1311 `COMMITTED_WITH_ONEPHASE` it means that the current participant
1312 didn't reach it but some other did so, keep the state as
1313 `PREPARED_IN_TC`/`COMMITTED_WITH_ONEPHASE`.
1314
1315 - If the parameter state is `PREPARED_IN_TC`, it means that other
1316 participants must have persisted either the PREPARE, the COMMIT or
1317 the ROLLBACK. In that case, keep whatever state is already there and
1318 ensure that is not `PREPARED_IN_SE`.
1319
1320 - If the parameter state is `COMMITTED_WITH_ONEPHASE`, `COMMITTED` or
1321 `ROLLEDBACK`, do nothing, only the active transaction coordinator has
1322 the ability, for now, to set the transaction state to those values.
1323
1324 @param xid The XID to be added (the key).
1325 @param xid The state to be added (the value).
1326
1327 @return The current value of the transaction state if the XID has
1328 already been added, Ha_recover_states::NOT_FOUND otherwise.
1329 */
1330 enum_ha_recover_xa_state add(XID const &xid, enum_ha_recover_xa_state state);
1331 /**
1332 Factory like method to instantiate all the infra-structure needed to
1333 create an `Xa_state_list`. Since such infra-structuer is dependent on
1334 `MEM_ROOT` and `Mem_root_allocator`, the method returns a tuple
1335 containing unique pointers to all 4 objects needed: MEM_ROOT;
1336 Mem_root_allocator; Xa_state_list::list; Xa_state_list.
1337
1338 @return An std::tuple containing unique pointers to all 4 objects
1339 needed: MEM_ROOT; Mem_root_allocator; Xa_state_list::list;
1340 Xa_state_list.
1341 */
1342 static Xa_state_list::instantiation_tuple new_instance();
1343
1344 private:
1345 /** The underlying map holding the trx and states*/
1346 Xa_state_list::list &m_underlying;
1347 };

1424 /** X/Open XA distributed transaction status codes */
1425 enum xa_status_code {
1426 /**
1427 normal execution
1428 */
1429 XA_OK = 0,
1430
1431 /**
1432 asynchronous operation already outstanding
1433 */
1434 XAER_ASYNC = -2,
1435
1436 /**
1437 a resource manager error occurred in the transaction branch
1438 */
1439 XAER_RMERR = -3,
1440
1441 /**
1442 the XID is not valid
1443 */
1444 XAER_NOTA = -4,
1445
1446 /**
1447 invalid arguments were given
1448 */
1449 XAER_INVAL = -5,
1450
1451 /**
1452 routine invoked in an improper context
1453 */
1454 XAER_PROTO = -6,
1455
1456 /**
1457 resource manager unavailable
1458 */
1459 XAER_RMFAIL = -7,
1460
1461 /**
1462 the XID already exists
1463 */
1464 XAER_DUPID = -8,
1465
1466 /**
1467 resource manager doing work outside transaction
1468 */
1469 XAER_OUTSIDE = -9
1470 };

1759
1760 /**
1761 Retrieve SDI for a given SDI key.
1762
1763 Since the caller of this api will not know the SDI length, SDI retrieval
1764 should be done in the following way.
1765
1766 i. Allocate initial memory of some size (Lets say 64KB)
1767 ii. Pass the allocated memory to the below api.
1768 iii. If passed buffer is sufficient, sdi_get_by_id() copies the sdi
1769 to the buffer passed and returns success, else sdi_len is modified
1770 with the actual length of the SDI (and returns false on failure).
1771 For genuine errors, sdi_len is returned as UINT64_MAX
1772 iv. If sdi_len != UINT64_MAX, retry the call after allocating the memory
1773 of sdi_len
1774 v. Free the memory after using SDI (responsibility of caller)
1775
1776 @param[in] tablespace tablespace object
1777 @param[in] sdi_key SDI key to uniquely identify SDI obj
1778 @param[in,out] sdi SDI retrieved from tablespace
1779 A non-null pointer must be passed in
1780 @param[in,out] sdi_len in: length of the memory allocated
1781 out: actual length of SDI
1782 @retval false success
1783 @retval true failure
1784 */
1785 typedef bool (*sdi_get_t)(const dd::Tablespace &tablespace,
1786 const sdi_key_t *sdi_key, void *sdi, uint64 *sdi_len);
1787
1788 /**
1789 Insert/Update SDI for a given SDI key.
1790 @param[in] hton handlerton object
1791 @param[in] tablespace tablespace object
1792 @param[in] table table object
1793 @param[in] sdi_key SDI key to uniquely identify SDI obj
1794 @param[in] sdi SDI to write into the tablespace
1795 @param[in] sdi_len length of SDI BLOB returned
1796 @retval false success
1797 @retval true failure, my_error() should be called
1798 by SE
1799 */
1800 typedef bool (*sdi_set_t)(handlerton *hton, const dd::Tablespace &tablespace,
1801 const dd::Table *table, const sdi_key_t *sdi_key,
1802 const void *sdi, uint64 sdi_len);
1803

1810 @retval true failure, my_error() should be called
1811 by SE
1812 */
1813 typedef bool (*sdi_delete_t)(const dd::Tablespace &tablespace,

1840 /**
1841 Retrieve cost constants to be used for this storage engine.
1842
1843 A storage engine that wants to provide its own cost constants to
1844 be used in the optimizer cost model, should implement this function.
1845 The server will call this function to get a cost constant object
1846 that will be used for tables stored in this storage engine instead
1847 of using the default cost constants.
1848
1849 Life cycle for the cost constant object: The storage engine must
1850 allocate the cost constant object on the heap. After the function
1851 returns, the server takes over the ownership of this object.
1852 The server will eventually delete the object by calling delete.
1853
1854 @note In the initial version the storage_category parameter will
1855 not be used. The only valid value this will have is DEFAULT_STORAGE_CLASS
1856 (see declaration in opt_costconstants.h).
1857
1858 @param storage_category the storage type that the cost constants will
1859 be used for
1860
1861 @return a pointer to the cost constant object, if NULL is returned
1862 the default cost constants will be used
1863 */
1864 typedef SE_cost_constants *(*get_cost_constants_t)(uint storage_category);

1869 @param[out] ptr_trx_arg double pointer to being replaced transaction
1870
1871 Associated with THD engine's native transaction is replaced
1872 with @c new_trx_arg. The old value is returned through a buffer if non-null
1873 pointer is provided with @c ptr_trx_arg.
1874 The method is adapted by XA start and XA prepare handlers to
1875 handle XA transaction that is logged as two parts by slave applier.
1876
1877 This interface concerns engines that are aware of XA transaction.
1878 */
1879 typedef void (*replace_native_transaction_in_thd_t)(THD *thd, void *new_trx_arg,
1880 void **ptr_trx_arg);

1988 /**
1989 Notify/get permission from storage engine before acquisition or after
1990 release of exclusive metadata lock on object represented by key.
1991
1992 @param thd Thread context.
1993 @param mdl_key MDL key identifying object on which exclusive
1994 lock is to be acquired/was released.
1995 @param notification_type Indicates whether this is pre-acquire or
1996 post-release notification.
1997 @param victimized 'true' if locking failed as we were selected
1998 as a victim in order to avoid possible deadlocks.
1999
2000 @note Notification is done only for objects from TABLESPACE, SCHEMA,
2001 TABLE, FUNCTION, PROCEDURE, TRIGGER and EVENT namespaces.
2002
2003 @note Problems during notification are to be reported as warnings, MDL
2004 subsystem will report generic error if pre-acquire notification
2005 fails/SE refuses lock acquisition.
2006 @note Return value is ignored/error is not reported in case of
2007 post-release notification.
2008
2009 @note In some cases post-release notification might happen even if
2010 there were no prior pre-acquire notification. For example,
2011 when SE was loaded after exclusive lock acquisition, or when
2012 we need notify SEs which permitted lock acquisition that it
2013 didn't happen because one of SEs didn't allow it (in such case
2014 we will do post-release notification for all SEs for simplicity).
2015
2016 @return False - if notification was successful/lock can be acquired,
2017 True - if it has failed/lock should not be acquired.
2018 */
2019 typedef bool (*notify_exclusive_mdl_t)(THD *thd, const MDL_key *mdl_key,
2020 ha_notification_type notification_type,
2021 bool *victimized);

2023 /**
2024 Notify/get permission from storage engine before or after execution of
2025 ALTER TABLE operation on the table identified by the MDL key.
2026
2027 @param thd Thread context.
2028 @param mdl_key MDL key identifying table which is going to be
2029 or was ALTERed.
2030 @param notification_type Indicates whether this is pre-ALTER TABLE or
2031 post-ALTER TABLE notification.
2032
2033 @note This hook is necessary because for ALTER TABLE upgrade to X
2034 metadata lock happens fairly late during the execution process,
2035 so it can be expensive to abort ALTER TABLE operation at this
2036 stage by returning failure from notify_exclusive_mdl() hook.
2037
2038 @note This hook follows the same error reporting convention as
2039 @see notify_exclusive_mdl().
2040
2041 @note Similarly to notify_exclusive_mdl() in some cases post-ALTER
2042 notification might happen even if there were no prior pre-ALTER
2043 notification.
2044
2045 @note Post-ALTER notification can happen before post-release notification
2046 for exclusive metadata lock acquired by this ALTER TABLE.
2047
2048 @return False - if notification was successful/ALTER TABLE can proceed.
2049 True - if it has failed/ALTER TABLE should be aborted.
2050 */
2051 typedef bool (*notify_alter_table_t)(THD *thd, const MDL_key *mdl_key,
2052 ha_notification_type notification_type);

2343 /**
2344 Prepare the secondary engine for executing a statement. This function is
2345 called right after the secondary engine TABLE objects have been opened by
2346 open_secondary_engine_tables(), before the statement is optimized and
2347 executed. Secondary engines will typically create a context object in this
2348 function, which they can use to store state that is needed during the
2349 optimization and execution phases.
2350
2351 @param thd thread context
2352 @param lex the statement to execute
2353 @return true on error, false on success
2354 */
2355 using prepare_secondary_engine_t = bool (*)(THD *thd, LEX *lex);
2356
2357 /**
2358 Optimize a statement for execution on a secondary storage engine. This
2359 function is called when the optimization of a statement has completed, just
2360 before the statement is executed. Secondary engines can use this function to
2361 apply engine-specific optimizations to the execution plan. They can also
2362 reject executing the query by raising an error, in which case the query will
2363 be reprepared and executed by the primary storage engine.
2364
2365 @param thd thread context
2366 @param lex the statement being optimized
2367 @return true on error, false on success
2368 */
2369 using optimize_secondary_engine_t = bool (*)(THD *thd, LEX *lex);

2371 /**
2372 Compares the cost of two join plans in the secondary storage engine. The cost
2373 of the current candidate is compared with the cost of the best plan seen so
2374 far.
2375
2376 @param thd thread context
2377 @param join the candidate plan to evaluate
2378 @param optimizer_cost the cost estimate calculated by the optimizer
2379 @param[out] use_best_so_far true if the optimizer should stop searching for
2380 a better plan and use the best plan it has seen so far
2381 @param[out] cheaper true if the candidate is the best plan seen so far for
2382 this JOIN (must be true if it is the first plan seen),
2383 false otherwise
2384 @param[out] secondary_engine_cost the cost estimated by the secondary engine
2385
2386 @return false on success, or true if an error has been raised
2387 */
2388 using compare_secondary_engine_cost_t = bool (*)(THD *thd, const JOIN &join,
2389 double optimizer_cost,
2390 bool *use_best_so_far,
2391 bool *cheaper,
2392 double *secondary_engine_cost);
2393
2394 /**
2395 Evaluates the cost of executing the given access path in this secondary
2396 storage engine, and potentially modifies the cost estimates that are in the
2397 access path. This function is only called from the hypergraph join optimizer.
2398
2399 The function is called on every access path that the join optimizer might
2400 compare to an alternative access path. This includes both paths that represent
2401 complete execution plans and paths that represent partial plans. It is not
2402 guaranteed to be called on every child path. For example, if GROUP BY is done
2403 by sorting first and then aggregating the sorted results, the function will
2404 only be called on the aggregation path, and not on the sort path, because only
2405 the aggregation path will be compared to other paths.
2406
2407 The secondary engine is allowed to modify the estimates in the access path to
2408 better match the costs of the access path in the secondary engine. It can
2409 change any of the following AccessPath members:
2410
2411 - init_once_cost
2412 - init_cost
2413 - cost
2414 - cost_before_filter
2415 - num_output_rows
2416 - num_output_rows_before_filter
2417 - secondary_engine_data
2418
2419 Any other members should be left unchanged. The AccessPath must be in an
2420 internally consistent state when the function returns, and satisfy invariants
2421 expected by the hypergraph join optimizer, such as:
2422
2423 - init_cost <= cost_before_filter <= cost
2424 - num_output_rows <= num_output_rows_before_filter
2425
2426 The secondary engine can also reject an access path altogether, by returning
2427 true, in which case the join optimizer will not use that path in the final
2428 plan. Since the secondary engine can reject any partial or complete plan, it
2429 is possible that the join optimizer does not find any valid plan that is
2430 accepted. In this case, the join optimizer will raise an error.
2431
2432 If the secondary encounters an error when evaluating the cost of the path, it
2433 can signal an error by calling my_error() and return true, in which case the
2434 join optimizer will not suggest any plan for the query.
2435
2436 @param thd The thread context.
2437 @param hypergraph The hypergraph that represents the search space.
2438 @param[in,out] access_path The AccessPath to evaluate.
2439
2440 @retval false on success.
2441 @retval true if the plan is to be rejected, or if an error was raised.
2442 */
2443 using secondary_engine_modify_access_path_cost_t = bool (*)(
2444 THD *thd, const JoinHypergraph &hypergraph, AccessPath *access_path);
2445
2446 // Capabilities (bit flags) for secondary engines.
2447 using SecondaryEngineFlags = uint64_t;
2448 enum class SecondaryEngineFlag : SecondaryEngineFlags {
2449 SUPPORTS_HASH_JOIN = 0,
2450 SUPPORTS_NESTED_LOOP_JOIN = 1,
2451
2452 // If this flag is set, aggregation (GROUP BY and DISTINCT) do not require
2453 // ordered inputs and create unordered outputs. This is typically the case
2454 // if they are implemented using hash-based techniques.
2455 AGGREGATION_IS_UNORDERED = 2
2456 };
2457
2458 /// Creates an empty bitmap of access path types. This is the base
2459 /// case for the function template with the same name below.
2460 10629 inline constexpr SecondaryEngineFlags MakeSecondaryEngineFlags() { return 0; }
2461
2462 /// Creates a bitmap representing a set of access path types.
2463 template <typename... Args>
2464 23844 constexpr SecondaryEngineFlags MakeSecondaryEngineFlags(
2465 SecondaryEngineFlag flag1, Args... rest) {
2466 23844 return (uint64_t{1} << static_cast<int>(flag1)) |
2467 23844 MakeSecondaryEngineFlags(rest...);
2468 }

2587 /**
2588 handlerton is a singleton structure - one instance per storage engine -
2589 to provide access to storage engine functionality that works on the
2590 "global" level (unlike handler class that works on a per-table basis).
2591
2592 usually handlerton instance is defined statically in ha_xxx.cc as
2593
2594 static handlerton { ... } xxx_hton;
2595
2596 savepoint_*, prepare, recover, and *_by_xid pointers can be 0.
2597 */
2598 struct handlerton {
2599 /**
2600 Historical marker for if the engine is available or not.
2601 */
2602 SHOW_COMP_OPTION state;
2603
2604 /**
2605 Historical number used for frm file to determine the correct storage engine.
2606 This is going away and new engines will just use "name" for this.
2607 */
2608 enum legacy_db_type db_type;
2609 /**
2610 Each storage engine has it's own memory area (actually a pointer)
2611 in the thd, for storing per-connection information.
2612 It is accessed as
2613
2614 thd->ha_data[xxx_hton.slot]
2615
2616 slot number is initialized by MySQL after xxx_init() is called.
2617 */
2618 uint slot;
2619 /**
2620 To store per-savepoint data storage engine is provided with an area
2621 of a requested size (0 is ok here).
2622 savepoint_offset must be initialized statically to the size of
2623 the needed memory to store per-savepoint information.
2624 After xxx_init it is changed to be an offset to savepoint storage
2625 area and need not be used by storage engine.
2626 see binlog_hton and binlog_savepoint_set/rollback for an example.
2627 */
2628 uint savepoint_offset;
2629
2630 /* handlerton methods */
2631
2632 close_connection_t close_connection;
2633 kill_connection_t kill_connection;
2634 pre_dd_shutdown_t pre_dd_shutdown;
2635 savepoint_set_t savepoint_set;
2636 savepoint_rollback_t savepoint_rollback;
2637 savepoint_rollback_can_release_mdl_t savepoint_rollback_can_release_mdl;
2638 savepoint_release_t savepoint_release;
2639 commit_t commit;
2640 rollback_t rollback;
2641 prepare_t prepare;
2642 recover_t recover;

2827 /* Possible flags of a handlerton (there can be 32 of them) */
2828 #define HTON_NO_FLAGS 0
2829 #define HTON_CLOSE_CURSORS_AT_COMMIT (1 << 0)
2830 #define HTON_ALTER_NOT_SUPPORTED (1 << 1) // Engine does not support alter
2831 #define HTON_CAN_RECREATE (1 << 2) // Delete all is used for truncate
2832 #define HTON_HIDDEN (1 << 3) // Engine does not appear in lists
2833 /*
2834 Bit 4 was occupied by BDB-specific HTON_FLUSH_AFTER_RENAME flag and is no
2835 longer used.
2836 */
2837 #define HTON_NOT_USER_SELECTABLE (1 << 5)
2838 #define HTON_TEMPORARY_NOT_SUPPORTED \
2839 (1 << 6) // Having temporary tables not supported
2840 #define HTON_SUPPORT_LOG_TABLES (1 << 7) // Engine supports log tables
2841 #define HTON_NO_PARTITION (1 << 8) // You can not partition these tables
2842
2843 /*
2844 This flag should be set when deciding that the engine does not allow row based
2845 binary logging (RBL) optimizations.
2846
2847 Currently, setting this flag, means that table's read/write_set will be left
2848 untouched when logging changes to tables in this engine. In practice this
2849 means that the server will not mess around with table->write_set and/or
2850 table->read_set when using RBL and deciding whether to log full or minimal
2851 rows.
2852
2853 It's valuable for instance for virtual tables, eg: Performance Schema which
2854 have no meaning for replication.
2855 */
2856 #define HTON_NO_BINLOG_ROW_OPT (1 << 9)
2857
2858 /**
2859 Engine supports extended keys. The flag allows to
2860 use 'extended key' feature if the engine is able to
2861 do it (has primary key values in the secondary key).
2862 Note that handler flag HA_PRIMARY_KEY_IN_READ_INDEX is
2863 actually partial case of HTON_SUPPORTS_EXTENDED_KEYS.
2864 */
2865
2866 #define HTON_SUPPORTS_EXTENDED_KEYS (1 << 10)
2867
2868 // Engine support foreign key constraint.
2869
2870 #define HTON_SUPPORTS_FOREIGN_KEYS (1 << 11)
2871
2872 /**
2873 Engine supports atomic DDL. That is rollback of transaction for DDL
2874 statement will also rollback all changes in SE, commit of transaction
2875 of DDL statement will make it durable.
2876 */
2877
2878 #define HTON_SUPPORTS_ATOMIC_DDL (1 << 12)
2879
2880 /* Engine supports packed keys. */
2881 #define HTON_SUPPORTS_PACKED_KEYS (1 << 13)
2882
2883 /** Engine is a secondary storage engine. */
2884 #define HTON_IS_SECONDARY_ENGINE (1 << 14)
2885
2886 /** Engine supports secondary storage engines. */
2887 #define HTON_SUPPORTS_SECONDARY_ENGINE (1 << 15)
2888
2889 /** Engine supports table or tablespace encryption . */
2890 #define HTON_SUPPORTS_TABLE_ENCRYPTION (1 << 16)

2907 constexpr const decltype(handlerton::flags) HTON_SUPPORTS_ENGINE_ATTRIBUTE{
2908 1 << 17};
2909
2910 /** Engine supports Generated invisible primary key. */
2911 constexpr const decltype(
2912 handlerton::flags) HTON_SUPPORTS_GENERATED_INVISIBLE_PK{1 << 18};
2913
2914 /**
2915 Set if the storage engine supports 'online' backups. This means that there
2916 exists a way to create a consistent copy of its tables without blocking
2917 updates to them. If so, statements that update such tables will not be
2918 affected by an active LOCK TABLES FOR BACKUP.
2919 */
2920 #define HTON_SUPPORTS_ONLINE_BACKUPS (1 << 19)
2921
2922 /**
2923 Engine supports secondary clustered keys.
2924 */
2925 #define HTON_SUPPORTS_CLUSTERED_KEYS (1 << 20)
2926
2927 /**
2928 Engine supports compressed columns.
2929 */
2930 #define HTON_SUPPORTS_COMPRESSED_COLUMNS (1 << 21)
2931
2932 26315 inline bool ddl_is_atomic(const handlerton *hton) {
2933 26315 return (hton->flags & HTON_SUPPORTS_ATOMIC_DDL) != 0;
2934 }
2935
2936 /* Bits for handlerton::foreign_keys_flags bitmap. */
2937
2938 /**
2939 Engine supports both unique and non-unique parent keys for
2940 foreign keys which contain full foreign key as its prefix.
2941
2942 Storage engines which support foreign keys but do not have
2943 this flag set are assumed to support only parent keys which
2944 are primary/unique and contain exactly the same columns as
2945 the foreign key, possibly, in different order.
2946 */
2947
2948 static const uint32 HTON_FKS_WITH_PREFIX_PARENT_KEYS = (1 << 0);
2949
2950 /**
2951 Storage engine supports hash keys as supporting keys for foreign
2952 keys. Hash key should contain all foreign key columns and only
2953 them (although in any order).
2954
2955 Storage engines which support foreign keys but do not have this
2956 flag set are assumed to not allow hash keys as supporting keys.
2957 */
2958
2959 static const uint32 HTON_FKS_WITH_SUPPORTING_HASH_KEYS = (1 << 1);
2960
2961 /**
2962 Storage engine supports non-hash keys which have common prefix
2963 with the foreign key as supporting keys for it. If there are
2964 several such keys, one which shares biggest prefix with FK is
2965 chosen.
2966
2967 Storage engines which support foreign keys but do not have this
2968 flag set are assumed to require that supporting key contains full
2969 foreign key as its prefix.
2970 */
2971
2972 static const uint32 HTON_FKS_WITH_ANY_PREFIX_SUPPORTING_KEYS = (1 << 2);
2973
2974 /**
2975 Storage engine does not support using the same key for both parent
2976 and supporting key, but requires the two to be different.
2977 */
2978
2979 static const uint32 HTON_FKS_NEED_DIFFERENT_PARENT_AND_SUPPORTING_KEYS =
2980 (1 << 3);
2981
2982 /**
2983 Engine takes into account hidden part of key (coming from primary key)
2984 when determines if it can serve as parent key for a foreign key.
2985
2986 Implies HTON_FKS_WITH_PREFIX_PARENT_KEYS and is related to
2987 HTON_SUPPORTS_EXTENDED_KEYS.
2988 */
2989
2990 static const uint32 HTON_FKS_WITH_EXTENDED_PARENT_KEYS = (1 << 4);
2991
2992 /**
2993 Maximum possible length of SE-specific suffixes for auto-generated
2994 foreign key names.
2995 */
2996 static const size_t MAX_FK_NAME_SUFFIX_LENGTH = 16;
2997
2998 /**
2999 Suffix for auto-generated foreign key names for tables in SE's which
3000 don't specify own suffix. I.e. for foreign keys on tables in such
3001 SE's generated names follow (table name)FK_NAME_DEFAULT_SUFFIX(FK number)
3002 pattern.
3003 */
3004 static const LEX_CSTRING FK_NAME_DEFAULT_SUFFIX = {STRING_WITH_LEN("_fk_")};

3175 /**
3176 Class describing changes to be done by ALTER TABLE.
3177 Instance of this class is passed to storage engine in order
3178 to determine if this ALTER TABLE can be done using in-place
3179 algorithm. It is also used for executing the ALTER TABLE
3180 using in-place algorithm.
3181 */
3182
3183 class Alter_inplace_info {
3184 public:
3185 /**
3186 Bits to show in detail what operations the storage engine is
3187 to execute.
3188
3189 All these operations are supported as in-place operations by the
3190 SQL layer. This means that operations that by their nature must
3191 be performed by copying the table to a temporary table, will not
3192 have their own flags here (e.g. ALTER TABLE FORCE, ALTER TABLE
3193 ENGINE).
3194
3195 We generally try to specify handler flags only if there are real
3196 changes. But in cases when it is cumbersome to determine if some
3197 attribute has really changed we might choose to set flag
3198 pessimistically, for example, relying on parser output only.
3199 */
3200 typedef ulonglong HA_ALTER_FLAGS;
3201
3202 // Add non-unique, non-primary index
3203 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ADD_INDEX = 1ULL << 0;
3204
3205 // Drop non-unique, non-primary index
3206 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS DROP_INDEX = 1ULL << 1;
3207
3208 // Add unique, non-primary index
3209 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ADD_UNIQUE_INDEX = 1ULL << 2;
3210
3211 // Drop unique, non-primary index
3212 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS DROP_UNIQUE_INDEX = 1ULL << 3;
3213
3214 // Add primary index
3215 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ADD_PK_INDEX = 1ULL << 4;
3216
3217 // Drop primary index
3218 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS DROP_PK_INDEX = 1ULL << 5;
3219
3220 // Add column
3221
3222 // Virtual generated column
3223 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ADD_VIRTUAL_COLUMN = 1ULL << 6;
3224 // Stored base (non-generated) column
3225 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ADD_STORED_BASE_COLUMN = 1ULL << 7;
3226 // Stored generated column
3227 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ADD_STORED_GENERATED_COLUMN = 1ULL << 8;
3228 // Add generic column (convenience constant).
3229 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ADD_COLUMN =
3230 ADD_VIRTUAL_COLUMN | ADD_STORED_BASE_COLUMN | ADD_STORED_GENERATED_COLUMN;
3231
3232 // Drop column
3233 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS DROP_VIRTUAL_COLUMN = 1ULL << 9;
3234 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS DROP_STORED_COLUMN = 1ULL << 10;
3235 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS DROP_COLUMN =
3236 DROP_VIRTUAL_COLUMN | DROP_STORED_COLUMN;
3237
3238 // Rename column
3239 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ALTER_COLUMN_NAME = 1ULL << 11;
3240
3241 // Change column datatype
3242 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ALTER_VIRTUAL_COLUMN_TYPE = 1ULL << 12;
3243 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ALTER_STORED_COLUMN_TYPE = 1ULL << 13;
3244
3245 /**
3246 Change column datatype in such way that new type has compatible
3247 packed representation with old type, so it is theoretically
3248 possible to perform change by only updating data dictionary
3249 without changing table rows.
3250 */
3251 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ALTER_COLUMN_EQUAL_PACK_LENGTH = 1ULL << 14;
3252
3253 /// A virtual column has changed its position
3254 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ALTER_VIRTUAL_COLUMN_ORDER = 1ULL << 15;
3255
3256 /// A stored column has changed its position (disregarding virtual columns)
3257 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ALTER_STORED_COLUMN_ORDER = 1ULL << 16;
3258
3259 // Change column from NOT NULL to NULL
3260 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ALTER_COLUMN_NULLABLE = 1ULL << 17;
3261
3262 // Change column from NULL to NOT NULL

4029 /**
4030 The handler class is the interface for dynamically loadable
4031 storage engines. Do not add ifdefs and take care when adding or
4032 changing virtual functions to avoid vtable confusion
4033
4034 Functions in this class accept and return table columns data. Two data
4035 representation formats are used:
4036 1. TableRecordFormat - Used to pass [partial] table records to/from
4037 storage engine
4038
4039 2. KeyTupleFormat - used to pass index search tuples (aka "keys") to
4040 storage engine. See opt_range.cc for description of this format.
4041
4042 TableRecordFormat
4043 =================
4044 [Warning: this description is work in progress and may be incomplete]
4045 The table record is stored in a fixed-size buffer:
4046
4047 record: null_bytes, column1_data, column2_data, ...
4048
4049 The offsets of the parts of the buffer are also fixed: every column has
4050 an offset to its column{i}_data, and if it is nullable it also has its own
4051 bit in null_bytes.
4052
4053 The record buffer only includes data about columns that are marked in the
4054 relevant column set (table->read_set and/or table->write_set, depending on
4055 the situation).
4056 <not-sure>It could be that it is required that null bits of non-present
4057 columns are set to 1</not-sure>
4058
4059 VARIOUS EXCEPTIONS AND SPECIAL CASES
4060
4061 If the table has no nullable columns, then null_bytes is still
4062 present, its length is one byte <not-sure> which must be set to 0xFF
4063 at all times. </not-sure>
4064
4065 If the table has columns of type BIT, then certain bits from those columns
4066 may be stored in null_bytes as well. Grep around for Field_bit for
4067 details.
4068
4069 For blob columns (see Field_blob), the record buffer stores length of the
4070 data, following by memory pointer to the blob data. The pointer is owned
4071 by the storage engine and is valid until the next operation.
4072
4073 If a blob column has NULL value, then its length and blob data pointer
4074 must be set to 0.
4075
4076
4077 Overview of main modules of the handler API
4078 ===========================================
4079 The overview below was copied from the storage/partition/ha_partition.h when
4080 support for non-native partitioning was removed.
4081
4082 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4083 MODULE create/delete handler object
4084 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4085 Object create/delete method. Normally called when a table object
4086 exists.
4087
4088 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4089 MODULE meta data changes
4090 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4091 Meta data routines to CREATE, DROP, RENAME table are often used at
4092 ALTER TABLE (update_create_info used from ALTER TABLE and SHOW ..).
4093
4094 Methods:
4095 delete_table()
4096 rename_table()
4097 create()
4098 update_create_info()
4099
4100 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4101 MODULE open/close object
4102 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4103 Open and close handler object to ensure all underlying files and
4104 objects allocated and deallocated for query handling is handled
4105 properly.
4106
4107 A handler object is opened as part of its initialisation and before
4108 being used for normal queries (not before meta-data changes always.
4109 If the object was opened it will also be closed before being deleted.
4110
4111 Methods:
4112 open()
4113 close()
4114
4115 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4116 MODULE start/end statement
4117 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4118 This module contains methods that are used to understand start/end of
4119 statements, transaction boundaries, and aid for proper concurrency
4120 control.
4121
4122 Methods:
4123 store_lock()
4124 external_lock()
4125 start_stmt()
4126 lock_count()
4127 unlock_row()
4128 was_semi_consistent_read()
4129 try_semi_consistent_read()
4130
4131 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4132 MODULE change record
4133 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4134 This part of the handler interface is used to change the records
4135 after INSERT, DELETE, UPDATE, REPLACE method calls but also other
4136 special meta-data operations as ALTER TABLE, LOAD DATA, TRUNCATE.
4137
4138 These methods are used for insert (write_row), update (update_row)
4139 and delete (delete_row). All methods to change data always work on
4140 one row at a time. update_row and delete_row also contains the old
4141 row.
4142 delete_all_rows will delete all rows in the table in one call as a
4143 special optimization for DELETE from table;
4144
4145 Bulk inserts are supported if all underlying handlers support it.
4146 start_bulk_insert and end_bulk_insert is called before and after a
4147 number of calls to write_row.
4148
4149 Methods:
4150 write_row()
4151 update_row()
4152 delete_row()
4153 delete_all_rows()
4154 start_bulk_insert()
4155 end_bulk_insert()
4156
4157 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4158 MODULE full table scan
4159 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4160 This module is used for the most basic access method for any table
4161 handler. This is to fetch all data through a full table scan. No
4162 indexes are needed to implement this part.
4163 It contains one method to start the scan (rnd_init) that can also be
4164 called multiple times (typical in a nested loop join). Then proceeding
4165 to the next record (rnd_next) and closing the scan (rnd_end).
4166 To remember a record for later access there is a method (position)
4167 and there is a method used to retrieve the record based on the stored
4168 position.
4169 The position can be a file position, a primary key, a ROWID dependent
4170 on the handler below.
4171
4172 All functions that retrieve records and are callable through the
4173 handler interface must indicate whether a record is present after the call
4174 or not. Record found is indicated by returning 0 and setting table status
4175 to "has row". Record not found is indicated by returning a non-zero value
4176 and setting table status to "no row".
4177 @see TABLE::set_found_row() and TABLE::set_no_row().
4178 By enforcing these rules in the handler interface, storage handler functions
4179 need not set any status in struct TABLE. These notes also apply to module
4180 index scan, documented below.
4181
4182 Methods:
4183
4184 rnd_init()
4185 rnd_end()
4186 rnd_next()
4187 rnd_pos()
4188 rnd_pos_by_record()
4189 position()
4190
4191 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4192 MODULE index scan
4193 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4194 This part of the handler interface is used to perform access through
4195 indexes. The interface is defined as a scan interface but the handler
4196 can also use key lookup if the index is a unique index or a primary
4197 key index.
4198 Index scans are mostly useful for SELECT queries but are an important
4199 part also of UPDATE, DELETE, REPLACE and CREATE TABLE table AS SELECT
4200 and so forth.
4201 Naturally an index is needed for an index scan and indexes can either
4202 be ordered, hash based. Some ordered indexes can return data in order
4203 but not necessarily all of them.
4204 There are many flags that define the behavior of indexes in the
4205 various handlers. These methods are found in the optimizer module.
4206
4207 index_read is called to start a scan of an index. The find_flag defines
4208 the semantics of the scan. These flags are defined in
4209 include/my_base.h
4210 index_read_idx is the same but also initializes index before calling doing
4211 the same thing as index_read. Thus it is similar to index_init followed
4212 by index_read. This is also how we implement it.
4213
4214 index_read/index_read_idx does also return the first row. Thus for
4215 key lookups, the index_read will be the only call to the handler in
4216 the index scan.
4217
4218 index_init initializes an index before using it and index_end does
4219 any end processing needed.
4220
4221 Methods:
4222 index_read_map()
4223 index_init()
4224 index_end()
4225 index_read_idx_map()
4226 index_next()
4227 index_prev()
4228 index_first()
4229 index_last()
4230 index_next_same()
4231 index_read_last_map()
4232 read_range_first()
4233 read_range_next()
4234
4235 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4236 MODULE information calls
4237 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4238 This calls are used to inform the handler of specifics of the ongoing
4239 scans and other actions. Most of these are used for optimisation
4240 purposes.
4241
4242 Methods:
4243 info()
4244 get_dynamic_partition_info
4245 extra()
4246 extra_opt()
4247 reset()
4248
4249 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4250 MODULE optimizer support
4251 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4252 NOTE:
4253 One important part of the public handler interface that is not depicted in
4254 the methods is the attribute records which is defined in the base class.
4255 This is looked upon directly and is set by calling info(HA_STATUS_INFO) ?
4256
4257 Methods:
4258 min_rows_for_estimate()
4259 get_biggest_used_partition()
4260 scan_time()
4261 read_time()
4262 records_in_range()
4263 estimate_rows_upper_bound()
4264 records()
4265
4266 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4267 MODULE print messages
4268 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4269 This module contains various methods that returns text messages for
4270 table types, index type and error messages.
4271
4272 Methods:
4273 table_type()
4274 get_row_type()
4275 print_error()
4276 get_error_message()
4277
4278 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4279 MODULE handler characteristics

4281 This module contains a number of methods defining limitations and
4282 characteristics of the handler (see also documentation regarding the
4283 individual flags).
4284
4285 Methods:

4301 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4302 MODULE compare records

4304 cmp_ref checks if two references are the same. For most handlers this is

4306 as reference and this can be the same even if memcmp says they are

4309 Methods:

4400 */

4612 /**
4613 Some non-virtual ha_* functions, responsible for reading rows,
4614 like ha_rnd_pos(), must ensure that virtual generated columns are
4615 calculated before they return. For that, they should set this
4616 member to true at their start, and check it before they return: if
4617 the member is still true, it means they should calculate; if it's
4618 false, it means the calculation has been done by some called
4619 lower-level function and does not need to be re-done (which is why
4620 we need this status flag: to avoid redundant calculations, for

5055 /**
5056 Cost estimate for doing a number of non-sequentially accesses
5057 against the storage engine. Such accesses can be either number
5058 of rows to read, or number of disk pages to access.
5059 Each handler implementation is free to interpret that as best
5060 suited, depending on what is the dominating cost for that
5061 storage engine.
5062
5063 This method is mainly provided as a temporary workaround for
5064 bug#33317872, where we fix problems caused by calling
5065 Cost_model::page_read_cost() directly from the optimizer.
5066 That should be avoided, as it introduced assumption about all
5067 storage engines being disk-page based, and having a 'page' cost.
5068 Furthermore, this page cost was even compared against read_cost(),
5069 which was computed with an entirely different algorithm, and thus
5070 could not be compared.
5071
5072 The default implementation still call Cost_model::page_read_cost(),
5073 thus behaving just as before. However, handler implementation may
5074 override it to call handler::read_cost() instead(), which probably
5075 will be more correct. (If a page_read_cost should be included
5076 in the cost estimate, that should preferable be done inside
5077 each read_cost() implementation)
5078
5079 Longer term we should consider to remove all page_read_cost()
5080 usage from the optimizer itself, making this method obsolete.
5081
5082 @param index the index number
5083 @param reads the number of accesses being made
5084
5085 @returns the estimated cost
5086 */
5087 virtual double page_read_cost(uint index, double reads);
5088
5089 /**
5090 Provide an upper cost-limit of doing a specified number of
5091 seek-and-read key lookups. This need to be comparable and
5092 calculated with the same 'metric' as page_read_cost.
5093
5094 @param reads the number of rows read in the 'worst' case.
5095
5096 @returns the estimated cost
5097 */
5098 virtual double worst_seek_times(double reads);

5693 /**
5694 Normally, when running UPDATE or DELETE queries, we need to wait for other
5695 transactions to release their locks on a given row before we can read it and
5696 potentially update it. However, in READ UNCOMMITTED and READ COMMITTED, we
5697 can ignore these locks if we don't intend to modify the row (e.g., because
5698 it failed a WHERE). This is signaled through enabling semi-consistent
5699 read, by calling try_semi_consistent_read(true) (and then setting it back
5700 to false after finishing the query).
5701
5702 If semi-consistent read is enabled, and we are in READ UNCOMMITTED or READ
5703 COMMITTED, the storage engine is permitted to return rows that are locked
5704 and thus un-updatable. If the optimizer doesn't want the row, e.g., because
5705 it got filtered out, it can call unlock_row() as usual. However, if it
5706 intends to update the row, it needs to call was_semi_consistent_read()
5707 before doing so. If was_semi_consistent_read() returns false, the row was
5708 never locked to begin with and can be updated as usual. However, if it
5709 returns 1, it was read optimistically, must be discarded (ie., do not try to
5710 update the row) and must be re-read with locking enabled. The next read call
5711 after was_semi_consistent_read() will automatically re-read the same row,
5712 this time with locking enabled.
5713
5714 Thus, typical use in an UPDATE scenario would look like this:
5715
5716 file->try_semi_consistent_read(true);
5717 file->ha_rnd_init(true);
5718 while (file->ha_rnd_next(table->record[0]) == 0) {
5719 if (row is filtered...) {
5720 file->unlock_row();
5721 continue;
5722 }
5723 if (file->was_semi_consistent_read()) {
5724 // Discard the row; next ha_rnd_next() will read it again with
5725 // locking.
5726 continue;
5727 }
5728 // Process row here.
5729 }
5730 file->ha_rnd_end();
5731 file->try_semi_consistent_read(false);
5732
5733 If the transaction isolation level is REPEATABLE READ or SERIALIZABLE,
5734 enabling this flag has no effect.
5735 */
5736 1332904 virtual bool was_semi_consistent_read() { return false; }
5737 /**
5738 Tell the engine whether it should avoid unnecessary lock waits.
5739 If yes, in an UPDATE or DELETE, if the row under the cursor was locked
5740 by another transaction, the engine may try an optimistic read of
5741 the last committed row value under the cursor.
5742 */
5743 677784 virtual void try_semi_consistent_read(bool) {}

5901 We return number of partitions we will lock multiplied with number of
5902 locks needed by each partition. Assists the above functions in allocating
5903 sufficient space for lock structures.

5912 /**
5913 Is not invoked for non-transactional temporary tables.
5914
5915 @note store_lock() can return more than one lock if the table is MERGE
5916 or partitioned.
5917
5918 @note that one can NOT rely on table->in_use in store_lock(). It may
5919 refer to a different thread if called from mysql_lock_abort_for_thread().
5920
5921 @note If the table is MERGE, store_lock() can return less locks
5922 than lock_count() claimed. This can happen when the MERGE children
5923 are not attached when this is called from another thread.
5924
5925 The idea with handler::store_lock() is the following:
5926
5927 The statement decided which locks we should need for the table
5928 for updates/deletes/inserts we get WRITE locks, for SELECT... we get
5929 read locks.
5930
5931 Before adding the lock into the table lock handler (see thr_lock.c)
5932 mysqld calls store lock with the requested locks. Store lock can now
5933 modify a write lock to a read lock (or some other lock), ignore the
5934 lock (if we don't want to use MySQL table locks at all) or add locks
5935 for many tables (like we do when we are using a MERGE handler).
5936
5937 In some exceptional cases MySQL may send a request for a TL_IGNORE;
5938 This means that we are requesting the same lock as last time and this
5939 should also be ignored.
5940
5941 Called from lock.cc by get_lock_data().
5942 */

6075
6076 /* On-line/in-place/instant ALTER TABLE interface. */
6077
6078 /*
6079 Here is an outline of on-line/in-place ALTER TABLE execution through
6080 this interface.
6081
6082 Phase 1 : Initialization
6083 ========================
6084 During this phase we determine which algorithm should be used
6085 for execution of ALTER TABLE and what level concurrency it will
6086 require.
6087
6088 *) This phase starts by opening the table and preparing description
6089 of the new version of the table.
6090 *) Then we check if it is impossible even in theory to carry out
6091 this ALTER TABLE using the in-place/instant algorithm. For example,
6092 because we need to change storage engine or the user has explicitly
6093 requested usage of the "copy" algorithm.
6094 *) If in-place/instant ALTER TABLE is theoretically possible, we continue
6095 by compiling differences between old and new versions of the table
6096 in the form of HA_ALTER_FLAGS bitmap. We also build a few
6097 auxiliary structures describing requested changes and store
6098 all these data in the Alter_inplace_info object.
6099 *) Then the handler::check_if_supported_inplace_alter() method is called
6100 in order to find if the storage engine can carry out changes requested
6101 by this ALTER TABLE using the in-place or instant algorithm.
6102 To determine this, the engine can rely on data in HA_ALTER_FLAGS/
6103 Alter_inplace_info passed to it as well as on its own checks.
6104 If the in-place algorithm can be used for this ALTER TABLE, the level
6105 of required concurrency for its execution is also returned.
6106 If any errors occur during the handler call, ALTER TABLE is aborted
6107 and no further handler functions are called.
6108 Note that in cases when there is difference between in-place and
6109 instant algorithm and user explicitly asked for usage of in-place
6110 algorithm storage engine MUST return one of values corresponding
6111 to in-place algorithm and not HA_ALTER_INPLACE_INSTANT from this
6112 method.
6113 *) Locking requirements of the in-place algorithm are compared to any
6114 concurrency requirements specified by user. If there is a conflict
6115 between them, we either switch to the copy algorithm or emit an error.
6116
6117 Phase 2 : Execution
6118 ===================
6119
6120 In this phase the operations are executed.
6121
6122 *) As the first step, we acquire a lock corresponding to the concurrency
6123 level which was returned by handler::check_if_supported_inplace_alter()
6124 and requested by the user. This lock is held for most of the
6125 duration of in-place ALTER (if HA_ALTER_INPLACE_SHARED_LOCK_AFTER_PREPARE
6126 or HA_ALTER_INPLACE_NO_LOCK_AFTER_PREPARE were returned we acquire an
6127 exclusive lock for duration of the next step only).
6128 For HA_ALTER_INPLACE_INSTANT we keep shared upgradable metadata lock
6129 which was acquired at table open time.
6130 *) After that we call handler::ha_prepare_inplace_alter_table() to give the
6131 storage engine a chance to update its internal structures with a higher
6132 lock level than the one that will be used for the main step of algorithm.
6133 After that we downgrade the lock if it is necessary.
6134 This step should be no-op for instant algorithm.
6135 *) After that, the main step of this phase and algorithm is executed.
6136 We call the handler::ha_inplace_alter_table() method, which carries out
6137 the changes requested by ALTER TABLE but does not makes them visible to
6138 other connections yet.
6139 This step should be no-op for instant algorithm as well.
6140 *) We ensure that no other connection uses the table by upgrading our
6141 lock on it to exclusive.
6142 *) a) If the previous step succeeds,
6143 handler::ha_commit_inplace_alter_table() is called to allow the storage
6144 engine to do any final updates to its structures, to make all earlier
6145 changes durable and visible to other connections.
6146 For instant algorithm this is the step during which SE changes are done.
6147 Engines that support atomic DDL only prepare for the commit during this
6148 step but do not finalize it. Real commit happens later when the whole
6149 statement is committed. Also in some situations statement might be rolled
6150 back after call to commit_inplace_alter_table() for such storage engines.
6151 In the latter special case SE might require call to
6152 handlerton::dict_cache_reset() in order to invalidate its internal table
6153 definition cache after rollback.
6154 b) If we have failed to upgrade lock or any errors have occurred during
6155 the handler functions calls (including commit), we call
6156 handler::ha_commit_inplace_alter_table() to rollback all changes which
6157 were done during previous steps.
6158
6159 All the above calls to SE are provided with dd::Table objects describing old
6160 and new version of table being altered. Engines which support atomic DDL are
6161 allowed to adjust object corresponding to the new version. During phase 3
6162 these changes are saved to the data-dictionary.
6163
6164
6165 Phase 3 : Final
6166 ===============
6167
6168 In this phase we:
6169
6170 a) For engines which don't support atomic DDL:
6171
6172 *) Update the SQL-layer data-dictionary by replacing description of old
6173 version of the table with its new version. This change is immediately
6174 committed.
6175 *) Inform the storage engine about this change by calling the
6176 handler::ha_notify_table_changed() method.
6177 *) Process the RENAME clause by calling handler::ha_rename_table() and
6178 updating the data-dictionary accordingly. Again this change is
6179 immediately committed.
6180 *) Destroy the Alter_inplace_info and handler_ctx objects.
6181
6182 b) For engines which support atomic DDL:
6183
6184 *) Update the SQL-layer data-dictionary by replacing description of old
6185 version of the table with its new version.
6186 *) Process the RENAME clause by calling handler::ha_rename_table() and
6187 updating the data-dictionary accordingly.
6188 *) Commit the statement/transaction.
6189 *) Finalize atomic DDL operation by calling handlerton::post_ddl() hook
6190 for the storage engine.
6191 *) Additionally inform the storage engine about completion of ALTER TABLE
6192 for the table by calling the handler::ha_notify_table_changed()
6193 method.
6194 *) Destroy the Alter_inplace_info and handler_ctx objects.
6195 */
6196
6197 /**
6198 Check if a storage engine supports a particular alter table in-place
6199
6200 @param altered_table TABLE object for new version of table.
6201 @param ha_alter_info Structure describing changes to be done
6202 by ALTER TABLE and holding data used
6203 during in-place alter.
6204
6205 @retval HA_ALTER_ERROR Unexpected error.

6237 */

6652 /**
6653 Is not invoked for non-transactional temporary tables.
6654
6655 Tells the storage engine that we intend to read or write data
6656 from the table. This call is prefixed with a call to handler::store_lock()
6657 and is invoked only for those handler instances that stored the lock.
6658
6659 Calls to @c rnd_init / @c index_init are prefixed with this call. When table
6660 IO is complete, we call @code external_lock(F_UNLCK) @endcode.
6661 A storage engine writer should expect that each call to
6662 @code ::external_lock(F_[RD|WR]LOCK @endcode is followed by a call to
6663 @code ::external_lock(F_UNLCK) @endcode. If it is not, it is a bug in MySQL.
6664
6665 The name and signature originate from the first implementation
6666 in MyISAM, which would call @c fcntl to set/clear an advisory
6667 lock on the data file in this method.
6668
6669 Originally this method was used to set locks on file level to enable
6670 several MySQL Servers to work on the same data. For transactional
6671 engines it has been "abused" to also mean start and end of statements
6672 to enable proper rollback of statements and transactions. When LOCK
6673 TABLES has been issued the start_stmt method takes over the role of
6674 indicating start of statement but in this case there is no end of
6675 statement indicator(?).
6676
6677 Called from lock.cc by lock_external() and unlock_external(). Also called
6678 from sql_table.cc by copy_data_between_tables().
6679
6680 @param thd the current thread
6681 @param lock_type F_RDLCK, F_WRLCK, F_UNLCK
6682
6683 @return non-0 in case of failure, 0 in case of success.
6684 When lock_type is F_UNLCK, the return value is ignored.
6685 */
6686 1380615 virtual int external_lock(THD *thd [[maybe_unused]],
6687 int lock_type [[maybe_unused]]) {
6688 1380615 return 0;
6689 }

7435 /**
7436 Stage of the recovery process where information is collected from the
7437 storage engines (SE), merged with information from the transaction
7438 coordinator (TC) and transactions states are determined and enforced.
7439
7440 Implemented heuristics is as follows:
7441
7442 1. The `commit_list` parameter contains the set of internally coordinated
7443 transactions that the TC ensures were marked as committed.
7444
7445 2. The `xa_state_list` parameter contains the list of externally
7446 coordinated transactions and their states, as recorded by the TC.
7447
7448 3. For each SE:
7449 a. Collect list of transactions found in `PREPARED_IN_TC` state in the
7450 SE and merge it with the information collected from the TC, in
7451 `xa_state_list`.
7452 b. Retrieve the list of transactions found in prepared state in the
7453 SE.
7454
7455 c. For each internally coordinated transactions found in prepared
7456 state:
7457 1. If the transaction is found in `commit_list`, commit it.
7458 2. If the transaction is NOT found in `commit_list` but
7459 `tc_heuristic_recover = TC_HEURISTIC_RECOVER_COMMIT`, commit it.
7460 3. Otherwise, roll it back.
7461
7462 d. For each externally coordinated transactions found in prepared
7463 state:
7464 1. If the transaction isn't found in `xa_state_list`, roll it back.
7465 2. If the transaction is found in `xa_state_list` in `COMMITTED`
7466 state, commit it.
7467 3. If the transaction is found in `xa_state_list` in `ROLLEDBACK`
7468 state, roll it back.
7469 4. If the transaction is found in `xa_state_list` in `PREPARED`
7470 state, ensure that the transaction state in the SE is
7471 `PREPARED_IN_TC`.
7472
7473 @param commit_list Set of XIDs of internally coordinated transactions
7474 found as been committed in the transaction coordinator
7475 state.
7476 @param xa_state_list Map between XIDs and states of externally
7477 coordinated transactions as found in the internal
7478 transaction coordinator state.
7479
7480 @return 0 if recovery was successfull, non-zero otherwise.
7481 */
7482 int ha_recover(Xid_commit_list *commit_list = nullptr,
7483 Xa_state_list *xa_state_list = nullptr);
7484
7485 /**
7486 Perform SE-specific cleanup after recovery of transactions.
7487
7488 @note SE supporting atomic DDL can use this method to perform
7489 post-DDL actions for DDL statements which were committed
7490 or rolled back during recovery stage.
7491 */
7492 void ha_post_recover();
